posts.text:
There's an attack vector here with implications beyond completely delegating the review to the LLM. 

I agree that reviewers should be sanctioned for lazily having an LLM write their review. And, I think researchers who try to manipulate tools a reviewer might invoke should be sanctioned as well.

reply_context.text:
It seems like a reasonable request, but a compromised LLM might omit the weakest parts of the paper from the suggested review outline.

Yes, reviewers should be more diligent. But I think it's unreasonable to expect LLMs will have no future role in the process at all.

posts.text:
It seems like a reasonable request, but a compromised LLM might omit the weakest parts of the paper from the suggested review outline.

Yes, reviewers should be more diligent. But I think it's unreasonable to expect LLMs will have no future role in the process at all.

reply_context.text:
because mechanisms >> intentions.

It's not unreasonable that a well-intentioned reviewer would use an LLM as a tool to facilitate the review in a way that might unintentionally bias their review. Consider if a reviewer prompted an LLM to create an outline of the paper.

posts.text:
because mechanisms >> intentions.

It's not unreasonable that a well-intentioned reviewer would use an LLM as a tool to facilitate the review in a way that might unintentionally bias their review. Consider if a reviewer prompted an LLM to create an outline of the paper.

reply_context.text: Why? The reviewer is responsible for every single word in your review, and thus the person at fault for giving a faulty review is the reviewer an nobody else. In addition, LLM review is not peer review, or we don't have the same definition of "peer".

posts.text: I.e. if you're using a transformer to model some cognitive thing, you're actually carrying into your solution an inductive bias for this kind of higher-order meta-modeling that Luiz describes. This is why transformers are so powerful and general.

reply_context.text: From a parametric perspective, you might be surprised to learn that we're sort of already doing this in practice. You can interpret the underlying "attention" mechanism of transformer models as a hypernetwork -- a NN that outputs a NN -- and the model is a stack of these. arxiv.org/abs/2406.05816

posts.text: Further, it's worrying to me that (to the best of my understanding), no one has systems in place for archiving digitally-originated content to human-readable physical media systematically. If we got thrown back into the dark ages, it would be pretty handy to have wikipedia on microfiche.

reply_context.text: Digital data is ephemeral by nature. We are paradoxically increasingly reliant on digital media. We should cherish what remaining physical copies of works we have (rather than destroying them) since it seems likely we will be increasingly generating fewer and fewer of them moving forward.

posts.text: Digital data is ephemeral by nature. We are paradoxically increasingly reliant on digital media. We should cherish what remaining physical copies of works we have (rather than destroying them) since it seems likely we will be increasingly generating fewer and fewer of them moving forward.

reply_context.text:
We simply don't have human-readable physical archives for the vast majority of content. I'm thinking like microfiche.

What got me thinking about this was the anthropic lawsuit, which reminded me that large digital book scanning archival projects are legally required to destroy the physical books.

This is a general paradox of technology/bureaucracy/efficiency.
